title: Boris Johnson discovers a bad deal is better than no deal
text:

At some point today we should find out if we have a Brexit deal.



Then we will have to wait to see if that deal is sellable to the DUP and the Tory right.



Although we have not seen the details, Boris Johnson is reported to have agreed in principle to a Border down the Irish Sea.



In an article for the Daily Telegraph a year ago the same Boris Johnson described such a plan as a “monstrosity” that would effectively “annex” Northern Ireland.



Now he appears to have concluded that a bad deal is better than a no deal.



Even if an agreement is reached in Brussels today and can be signed off at the EU summit tomorrow the UK has been warned that it could take until January 1 to sort out the technical details.



This is clearly uncomfortable for a Prime Minister who pledged we would leave on October 31 “do or die.”

(Image: Getty Images)





The easy rhetoric used to win a leadership election has now come back to haunt him when faced with the hard choices of government.

If Johnson does land a deal there will an element of Nixon in China here - only a Republican president with authentic right-wing credentials could been seen to talk to the Communists.



So it may take a true Brexiteer to convince other Brexiteers to compromise.



But we are a long way from that stage.



A man forced to negotiate by the Surrender Act (Benn Act) may have committed the ultimate surrender.



The DUP, who were in Downing Street again last night, have yet to commit to backing the PM’s proposed agreement.



Though that may change if a sufficient number of pound signs are dangled before their eyes.



There are also divisions among the Tory MPs of the European Research Group with diehards such as Owen Paterson and Iain Duncan Smith voicing concerns about Johnson’s reported capitulation.



Could Paterson and Duncan Smith be stripped of the whip if they vote against the deal?



You would need to be an emotional block of granite not to relish such a prospect.

(Image: Getty Images)

That said, the vote could also pose problems for Jeremy Corbyn if a sizeable group of Labour MPs decide to back Johnson’s deal when it comes to a Commons vote.



If he fails to discipline them then he risks being painted by the Lib Dems as the leader of a party that helped enable Brexit.



To cause Labour more discomfort, the Lib Dems are tabling an amendment to the Queen’s Speech calling for any deal to be put to a second referendum.



As noted yesterday Labour is heading in this direction but is not there yet with its official line wanting a referendum after the party has negotiated its own deal.



Jeremy Corbyn will not like being bounced into a position by the Lib Dems nor watching some of his MPs join them in the voting lobby.

9.45am - The new Transport Secretary, Grant Shapps, is grilled by the Transport committee.

4pm - Boris Johnson updates Cabinet on the state of the Brexit negotiations.



7.30pm - Boris Johnson to address 1922 Committee of backbench Tory MPs.

description: The Prime Minister is trying to sell a deal he described last year as a "monstrosity"
